ref:
D: What brings you in?

P: Hi, uhm, I've just been a little bit worried, that last the couple of months I've noticed that I've been getting more and more out of breath when I've been doing exercise, and I know I got a brother who had a heart issue and I'm just really concerned that I have something wrong with my ticker, just wanted to get it checked out, you know?

D: Uhm, when did the shortness of breath start?

P: So, this winter specifically, like we haven't been too active because of Covid this year, we've just been staying in the house all last year, but with the snow, I'd be shovelling snow whenever it fell and before I could be able to like 2 years ago be able to clear the driveway, no problem, but now even after half the driveway I've noticed I'm getting consisntely out of breath, I've got this nasty cough and it's prompted my wife to get me to call in, she's a little bit worried.

D: So it's mostly on exertion, it doesn't happen at rest, is that correct?

P: Being out of breath? No, no.

D: No, OK, ok. And has this ever happened to you before?

P: Yeah, about a year and a half ago we went down to Toronto, in order to see the CN tower, and you know, do tourist stuff and we tried we tried to climb a couple flights of stairs to do a little bit, and I could not, I always thought I'm pretty healthy, pretty active but it really took the wind out of my sails, so had to stop, stoop over. Just couldn't do it.

D: Uhm, and how did you manage like how, how was that treated at that time and how did you get better?

P: Oh, I didn't do any. I just attributed to being, I don't know, out of shape a little bit and I worked as a mechanic when I was younger. I was pretty active, but ever since retiring thought I'd keep up, at least my stamina won't go away that quickly, but chalked it up to being out of shape and went home.

D: OK. Uhm, so your symptom, your shortness of breath seems to be getting worse, right?

P: Yeah.

D: OK, any coughing with that?

P: Yeah, yeah. And not necessarily when I noticed it when I was shovelling the driveway. But I've had a call for the last couple of years and usually in the morning I just bring up a little bit of gunk, but most of my buddies have that, just like a morning cough, you know?

D: Yeah, and the gunk that you bring up. What color is it?

P: Uh, yellow, sometimes a little brown.

D: OK, and when did that start?

P: Oh, it's been going on last 10 years. Well, to be honest since I've been like 30, but it's been fairly consistent, last 10 years I'd say.

D: OK, any blood that you bring up?

P: Not that I've noticed, like bright red? No, nothing like that.

D: OK. Any wheeziness?

P: Yeah yeah, I noticed that when I was showing, yeah when I was out of breath, it sound sounded different sound different than being usually out of breath but it had to. It sounded wheezy.

D: OK. Any chest pain?

P: Yeah, a little bit actually.

D: Uhm, at rest or?

P: Nothing, nothing when I'm not moving.

D: OK, so the chest pain, when did that start?

P: First noticed it this winter on the driveway but it wasn't like I know what they say about a heart attack, supposed to like, the crushing pain in your chest that moves up your neck. Nothing like that. It's like my lungs, my throat. Like you're really, really out of breath, you know?

D: OK, so you're attributing it mostly to your shortness of breath then?

P: I think so. I really hope this is my heart. I've never had a heart attack.

D: Yeah. Where in your chest is this chest pain happening like is it central? Is it more towards the left, towards the right?

P: It was kind of both sides.

D: OK.

P: It was, Was we all across my chest, to be honest it was only the one time that was really struggling and I coughed up a bit, but yeah.

D: OK, any pain in your calves or legs, well after you walk a certain distance?

P: No, no.

D: No. Do you ever feel like your heart's racing?

P: Felt like my heart was racing after that much activity, but no, not usually.

D: OK. How about swelling in your limbs?

P: No, nothing like that.

D: OK, any fainting spells or dizziness?

P: No never fainted in my life.

D: OK. Any confusion, memory loss?

P: No, nothing like that.

D: Headaches?

P: Headaches, you know I do get headaches from time to time. I associate them with stress, but I haven't been too stressed out recently so nothing in the last couple of years.

D: OK, any neck stiffness?

P: Uh, no.

D: No, OK. Any sensitivity to light or loud sounds associated with that headache?

P: No, nothing like that.

D: OK, any weight loss?

P: No, I wish.

D: OK. Fevers?

P: No.

D: Rashes?

P: You know I got these weird things on my head. I think mainly because of the sun. Like these brown patches, but that wouldn't be a rash, would it?

D: I'd have to examine that closer. If you think it's associated with the sun, it could be something like seborrheic keratosis, but I'd have to see what they look like so we can take a look at that later, if that's OK. And so any changes in your vision or hearing?

P: No.

D: No. Stuffy nose, runny nose?

P: Had a bit of a cold couple months ago, but no, nothing recent.

D: Sore throat?

P: Yeah, a little bit after the cough. I had a little bit of a sore throat but went away pretty quickly.

D: OK. Change in smell or taste?

P: I haven't been able to smell or taste too well for awhile.

D: What's awhile?

P: Ten years, seven years it's been more salt, more spices on my food, you know.

D: OK, OK. Any changes to your bowel habits?

P: Nope, been regular all my life.

D: Nausea, vomiting?

P: No.

D: OK. Joint pain, muscle aches?

P: You know my knees been giving me trouble for awhile, but nothing recent, no.

D: OK, and are you otherwise healthy?

P: No, got high blood pressure. See the doc about that. Uhm, high cholesterol, see the doc about that. And yeah, I don't know. Got into a car crash my 40s. Broke my arm one time. Nothing else really.

D: OK, any surgeries?

P: Uh, I think I had my appendix out when I was, yeah I had my appendix out when I was like 12.

D: OK.

P: Never been under the knife since then.

D: OK, great. Have you been taking any medications for that high blood pressure?

P: Yeah doc's got me on two blood pressure medications and one cholesterol medication.

D: OK, and do you take those frequently?

P: Yeah, everyday.

D: OK, good. Any other medications?

P: No.

D: Are you up to date with all your immunizations?

P: Jeez, been a while since I've gotten immunization. Think, I think so.

D: OK. Once you turn 65, they usually give you shing-shingrex for, to prevent shingles and a pneumovax vaccine to prevent pneumococcal infections. Have you had those ones?

P: Nope.

D: No, OK. So if you're interested in getting those, we can discuss that at some point today as well,

P: OK.

D: Do you have any allergies?

P: No.

D: No, OK. Any, OK, so you mentioned a family history of your brother having congenital heart disease. Any other heart diseases that run in the family?

P: Congenital. What's that mean?

D: Like something that you're born with.

P: No, I don't think he's ever born thing he had a couple of heart attacks.

D: Oh heart attacks. OK sorry I must have misinterpreted that. How old was he when he had his first heart attack?

P: He's older me by five years, but he had the first one when he was younger than I am now. Like 62 was the first one, another one at 65.

D: OK. Uhm, did, is he, did they ever find a cause for his heart attack? Is he a healthy person?

P: Healthy, he's healthy. I you know I wouldn't call him too healthy of a guy either. He's a hard liver, let's call him that. I have why it happened, I think, obviously it's his diet man. He's like a hog. Steaks, butter, bacon I'm  assuming that's what did him in.

D: Oh yikes, OK. OK, uh any other heart conditions that run in the family or other members of the family experiencing heart attacks?

P: Yep, dad died young from a high heart attack. He was, he died younger than I am now. He passed away at 66.

D: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that.

P: Oh it's been years now. It is what it is. His grandmother had a stroke. High blood pressure on my mom side. High cholesterol on my mom side too. But yeah, awful heart attacks on my father side of the family.

D: OK. Any other lung, any lung conditions that run in the family?

P: None that come to mind.

D: OK and do you smoke?

P: Yeah, yeah I smoke.

D: OK, how much do you smoke?

P: I cut it back, about half a pack a day for the last two years now.

D: OK and before that?

P: I was pretty much a pack a day. Maybe, well, when it was bad, 2 packs a day, but I've been smoking yeah, since about, when do they start working at the shop, like 17, everyone there smokes.

D: Oh OK Wow yeah well then but it's good that you cut down, that's good. Do you, do any other recreational drugs like marijuana, cocaine, heroin, anything?

P: I'll smoke weed at the shop every Friday, but I'm not huge fan of it to be honest.

D: OK. And how much do you smoke every Friday?

P: Both are about four joints, seven people, so I don't know what that is. Half a gram?

D: Half a joint? OK, yeah. OK, and do you drink?

P: Oh yeah.

D: How much do you drink?

P: See, Christmas was about the last time I went out like a beer or two. Uhm, weekends but when families in town will we'll go whole hog. I'll drink maybe 20 beer.

D: Oh OK, OK. And yeah you should, have you thought about cutting that down?

P: You gotta keep up with the family, you know, you can't let them embarrass you like that.

D: Let's, I understand that, but also you know, it's important to take care of your health and slow and steady wins the race, right?

P: I'll keep that in mind, doc, I'll keep that in mind.

D: Yeah, and how's your diet?

P: Been pretty good. The wife's been on a, on a health food craze last five years. Vegetables, I don't know, I eat whatever she cooks, basically.

D: OK. Uhm that's good, and in terms of exercise, do you get to move around?

P: I used to be pretty active. I used to bike around, but 'cause of Covid I've just been indoors all this time. So no, not much.

D: OK. OK, well it's good to go out for a walk once in awhile. I think that's allowed during Covid as long as you're being safe. And who do you live with at home?

P: I live with my wife.

D: OK, any children?

P: Yeah, I've got three kids, one for my first marriage, two with the Mrs. right now.

D: OK, and do you get to see them often?

P: Yeah, daughter lives in town and get to see her and grand kid a bit, the other boy works in Fort Mac and my oldest son, he's out east.

D: OK, OK, and have you had any contact with people who've been sick recently?

P: No, we've been keeping entirely to ourselves. You can get our groceries ordered to the house.

D: OK. And how about travel? Any recent travel?

P: No.

D: No, OK. Uhm, and then lastly, just wanted to ask you because you have been smoking for a long time, have you ever been diagnosed with something called COPD?

P: Doesn't ring a bell.

D: No, OK. Have you ever had any pulmonary function tests or chest x-rays done in the past?

P: Chest x-ray, I think they did a chest x-ray after the car crash.

D: OK.

P: But I can't think of getting one recently, no.

D: OK. Alright well those are all the questions that I had for you. Did you have any questions for me?

P: So this is a hard, like, should I be worried?

D: Yeah, you know what? It sounds from what you're telling me, it sounds like you have shortness of breath on exertion, and it sounds like you have a cough with still producing some phlegm. It doesn't seem like you have any systemic symptoms of infection, so I'm not too worried about that. And then in terms of your heart, you mentioned you had that chest pain once, but it really does sound more like a lung problem to me than a heart problem to me right now, but of course we'll do all the necessary investigations to rule out any heart stuff. But right now, I'm thinking it could be something called COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder because of your smoking history. Uhm, so we'll start with doing a pulmonary function test and chest x-ray, and I we'll try to go from there. If it is COPD we'll likely put you on a, like a puffer for that. A like a lot a short or long acting beta agonist, that's what it's called. So if your symptoms don't get better with that, we'll do other investigations to try to figure out what this is. How does that sound?

P: Sounds great, doc. Thanks a million.

D: Alright, great thank you.

P: Have a good one.

P: Been pretty good. The wife's been on a health food craze last five years. Vegetables. I don't know. I eat whatever she cooks, basically.

D: Okay. Well, it's good to go out for a walk once in a while. I think that's allowed during COVID, as long as you're being safe. And who do you live with at home?

P: I live with my wife.

D: Okay. Any children?

P: Yeah. I've got three kids. One for my first marriage. Two with the missus right now.

D: Okay. Do you get to see them often?

P: Yeah. Daughter lives in town. I get to see her and the grandkid a little bit. Other boy works at Fort Mac. And my oldest son, he's out east.

D: Okay. And have you had any contacts with people who've been sick recently?

P: No, we've been keeping entirely to ourselves. We even get our groceries ordered to the house.

P: Nope.

D: No.

D: Okay.

P: Sounds great, Doc. Thanks a million.

D: All right. Great. Thank you. Have a good one.
